awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Testing Models of Calcite Microcrystal Diagenesis Through Experiments, Geochemistry, and Advanced Imaging
awd_abstract_narration:
The resources contained in underground geologic reservoirs are key to the economic activity and vitality of communities, companies, and countries. To develop these resources in a cost-effective manner, it is vital to understand the plumbing of these reservoirs-specifically how big the pores (open spaces) are in the rocks, how well they are connected, and what kind of fluids they hold. This study focuses on small pores, called micropores, to understand how they form, and how they change as they are buried in the Earth. This knowledge will allow people such as farmers, water plant managers, and the oil and gas industry to drill fewer wells, increasing their economic competitiveness and decreasing disturbances to the environment and people. Micropores are also responsible for premature deterioration of roads constructed with crushed limestone. Therefore, the results from this work could lead to more robust highways, reducing construction and maintenance costs, while providing a safer and smoother ride for drivers. 

Previous work shows that most micropores are hosted in a framework of calcite microcrystals. The current research aims to understand the fundamental controls on the textures of these microcrystals in limestones. Numerous generalized pathways for calcite microcrystal formation and evolution have been proposed. None, however, has tied microcrystal texture to diagenetic process in a robust manner. Our aim is to integrate laboratory experiments, advanced imaging, and high-resolution geochemical techniques to better understand the diagenesis of calcite microcrystals and thus the micropores between them. Specifically, we propose to use experiments and a wide variety of natural samples to assess the geochemical heterogeneity and genetic evolution of the various calcite microcrystal textures. We hypothesize that spatial variations in microcrystal chemistry will reveal that the different microcrystal textures correlate to positions along a diagenetic trajectory of increasing cementation (i.e., microcrystal textures become more fitted with progressive burial and cementation).

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The goal of this collaborative research project was to better understand the geological processes and conditions whereby carbonate sediments deposited at the Earth's surface are lithified to limestone. Researchers at Western Michigan University employed hundreds of laboratory experiments to investigate the reaction whereby an unstable assortment of calcium carbonate minerals, such as aragonite and high-magnesium calcite (i.e. precursors), undergo a mineralogical transformation to more stable low-magnesium calcite (LMC) products after deposition. Previous research suggests that this mineralogical stabilization process is widespread, and is responsible for creating the vast majority of ancient limestones in the rock record, which are comprised of LMC microcrystals exhibiting a wide range of textural characteristics. When, where, and how the transformation from unstable carbonate sediments to LMC microcrystals occurs, and what controls the development of the various LMC micro-textures, is poorly understood, however. Scientific understanding of this processes is critical given that the composition of ancient limestones is routinely used to infer past conditions. More practically, the LMC microcrystals that comprise ancient limestones can host significant amounts of groundwater and producible hydrocarbons and could be permanent storages for anthropogenic carbon capture.

The project outcomes - all of which have been published in peer-reviewed scientific journals and are publically available - have advanced our knowledge of this process in a number of significant ways. In Hashim and Kaczmarek (2020), the first comprehensive study to experimentally evaluate the controls on LMC microcrystal size and texture it was shown that LMC micro-texture is controlled by fluid chemistry, fluid:solid ratio, and precursor type. In Hashim and Kaczmarek (2021a) it was shown that some LMC microcrystals can undergo further textural changes in when exposed to specific geological conditions. Hashim and Kaczmarek (2021b) further showed that contrary to previous claims stabilization from aragonite to LMC can occur in fluids with a high concentration of Mg, such as marine waters, but only when the fluid:solid ratio is very low. This observation implies that aragonite to LMC stabilization most likely occur during burial, when sediments are progressively isolated from the overlying marine waters. This study also shows for the first time that the amount of magnesium incorporated into the LMC microcrystals is controlled by the fluid:solid ratio. Findings from these experimental studies are used by Hashim and Kaczmarek (in review) to suggest that although stabilization occurs in a wide range of geological settings, the shallow burial setting is most common based on the observation that most LMC microcrystals are polyhedral. In contrast, stabilization in meteoric (rain) fluids produces rhombic microcrystals, which are far rarer in the geological record.

The results of this study have been published in peer-reviewed scientific journals and presented at a variety of professional and scientific conferences. The data and key outcomes are freely accessible to academic and industry researchers worldwide, and provide a basis for future research on the topic of LMC microcrystals. The outcomes of this project were specifically presented to industry professionals during industry-oriented conferences as well as invited talks given by the PI to teams working in the petroleum industry. These activities will increase the ties between academia and industry and help develop applied projects with direct benefit to the industry.

The LMC microcrystals that comprise ancient limestones are commonly used as climatological, biological, and sedimentological records of Earth?s past. Understanding the processes and geological settings responsible for altering these deposits after the time of deposition is critical to accurately reconstructing these records. Reconstructing Earth's climate in the past is important as it helps scientists predict future climate. This has important and direct benefits to society because it provides a better understanding of climate-related crisis that impact society directly such as sea level rise, global warming, and ocean acidification.

Understand how LMC micro-crystals form also helps industry professionals better understand and predict the occurrence of limestone microporosity, which impacts how fluids accumulate and migrate in the subsurface. The results from this study can be used to populate 3-D geological models of the subsurface. These models are of tremendous value to both geologists and engineers and have broad implications. For example, they can be used to simulate groundwater flow, aid in tracing harmful contaminants, identify drilling targets and enhance oil and gas production, which can both lead to less drilling, and reduce environmental impacts.

Lastly, this research was conducted in a publicly funded university and has benefitted a number of graduate and undergraduate students. This project provided educational and training opportunities to graduate and undergraduate students (two of whom are women) with the goal of developing a globally competitive STEM workforce.
